original_speakers: NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MADASA

testimony: Thank you Mr Chairman.  May I call Bennet Mnyaka Ndabe.
What language are you going to speak?
Mr Ndabe, how old are you?
How far did you go at school?
In the SDU, were you a patroller or an operator?
In the killings of December 1993, were you involved?
No.  I only participated in capturing (indistinct)
How did it come about that you were involved in capturing those people?
In the morning just after sunrise we left, myself and Sonti and Shuga.  We had been sent to report to Mnyala that the youth has already attacked people.
I don't remember quite well, whether that was from the community or himself, as he was a member of the Executive Defence.  I just escorted him or accompanied him.
This day that you are talking about, is this the day of the killing or is it the day when Blanko and Bulelwa died?
Where did you meet these people who sent you?
That is where we were, we were keeping guard the whole night.
We were quite many in number plus the community of Block F.
Were you asked to guard the corpse or did you go there voluntarily?
It is our culture as black people, we can't leave our corpse alone.
Did you hear that Bulelwa had died or how did it come about that you went to her body?
As part of the group, we heard the whistle blow.
You heard a whistle, and then you went to Bulelwa's body?

Perhaps Mr Ndabe, if you could just tell us how it came to be that you were at the spot where Bulelwa's body was found and how it came about that you went with Sonti and Shuga to make a report to Mnyala and what happened thereafter, do you understand that?
I don't quite understand what you want.

I am saying you have already told us that you did not kill anyone.  What you did was to escort or accompany the people who were going to capture and you took part there, and you have already made mention of the fact that as a man who belonged to that particular organisation or group, you had to go as part of the culture to where the corpse was.
	You were in the company of Sonti and Shuga to convey the report to Mnyala.

Now, what I am asking from you please concisely explain to us as to how did it come about that you landed right next to Bulelwa's corpse and found yourself going to Mnyala, and also we want to know what happened subsequently, in other words we want for you to explain to us exactly what you did.

The way we used to operate was in this fashion, if there is a place that has been attacked, we would hear a whistle blow, because people will alert us by blowing the whistle, and we will run to this thing where this whistle was being blown.
	That is exactly what happened on that particular day.  We heard the whistle and we had to rush in the direction where the whistle was being blown from and that is what we found Bulelwa's corpse.
We were there for quite some time, and some other comrades that is next to the corpse, some other comrades left to go and sleep at night, since they had to go to work the following morning.

Towards the early hours of the morning, or at dawn, we heard sounds of gun fire.  Suddenly there was fire.  We had to rush there with some other men who were with me around the corpse of Bulelwa that is.
	We found Blanko's shack burning fiercely.  We were quite many in number and we tried to extinguish the fire.  Then comrade Oscar arrived and explained to us, he was already from Sonti.  He was telling us, that is Oscar, who killed the person, who killed Blanko and was seen killing Blanko.
Did he tell you who did he see?
He did mention his name.  He said Tusaneng was the person.

We therefore left and went back to Bulelwa's corpse, some of us that is.    Some left in search of some other people like Ntshebe Dondolo.  I forgot the other one who used to be a Chairman at F, Nxeba, I just remembered.  His name is Nxeba.
	They went.  They went to fetch the Peace Committee at the hospital to fetch the corpse.
Comrades left us there by the corpse.  When Nxeba's car drove towards B or A, I am not too sure, we also heard gun shots at that point.

When these men followed towards that direction, they came across the other group and more gun shots were heard and we were still there, keeping guard at the corpse, so we don't know exactly what was happening, we just saw them coming back with youth.
	It was Nongeba Sonti and Shuga was also there.  I don't know the others.
Do you know those kids they brought back?
Those kids were taken to a shack which was near, just closer to where Bulelwa's corpse was laying.
Rooivalk was chosen and somebody else, to keep guard.

The group left again, going to locate as to where Nxeba was.  When they came back, they brought more kids and claimed that they met them somewhere, and Tusaneng was amongst that group if I am not mistaken this time around.
And when they arrived, they were also forwarded to the shack.
Did they return with one person or more than one person?
I don't know how many they were, but it was a group.
Early in the morning, I felt so sleepy, I felt I wanted to go to bed and sleep and I joined Nxeba as they were leaving, I left with them.
I was going with them to where they were going, they were going to Mnyala's house.   We met Tsepo at the taxi rank and we asked him about the matter that transpired yesterday since he was also sent.
And he told us that they were shot and one escaped and no one could tell as to who was running into which direction and so forth.
And he went to sleep wherever he slept and we left him alone and we got into a taxi and we told him where to go to a meeting where people had gathered.
The taxi took us to Mnyala and we alighted.
Just after getting out of the taxi, we saw Mnyala standing with Nxeba and three boys that belonged to the youth.
When we alighted from the taxi, we approached their direction.  One ran, fled and shot at us at the same time as he was running.
Do you know who that was?
Yes, he was shooting towards our direction, but no one got shot as he was also running.
When we searched them, we discovered a pistol from one of them.  That I handed over to the Committee, the pistol as Shuga was also part of the Committee member, SDU Committee.
Mnyala said we should go with them to 6, he will follow.
Yes, we went with them.  He said he will follow us later.
Indeed, we went with them to 6.
Who took them to the shack?
Shuga went with them to the shack.
Which shack, the one that was next to Bulelwa's body?
The first shack that was closer to where Bulelwa's corpse was laying.
I left after that and I went to my house, since I did not sleep at night.  Just between Block D and Block E, there is an open veld there at E.
I met the mother of one of the late or the deceased.
Do you know her, her names?

I don't know the name, all I know it is Pinky's mother.  She asked me as to where her child was.  She mentioned the name, I said I don't know the name, I don't know exactly.  I don't remember the name she mentioned, but she did mention a name to me.
What is the name, you said you met somebody's mother - Pinky?
She had to explain and describe the clothes that the girl was wearing, or the child was wearing.
After she described the child, I said the child is there in the shack.  And I also told her that people are still there.
And I left her and went on ahead to my house to sleep.
Did you participate further in anything?
I slept in my house.  I woke up in the afternoon.
Do you know anything about the killings?
I heard about that when I met the other comrades.
Why did you participate in rounding up those boys?
I was a SDU member and we were protecting the community or guarding the community.
I thought you said you had been tired of remaining near the corpse?  I thought you had said you were tired of guarding the corpse?
Yes.   When I left with Sonti I was beginning to feel dizzy and sleepy because I hadn't slept.
You went to capture those boys because you were tired?
I was tired of just sitting, because as I was sitting, I was falling asleep, so I had to do some action.
Why did you join Sonti and others to collect more people?
As I have already explained, I said that I was sitting down, I was falling asleep as a result of sitting down.  Now, I felt I had to do something to get involved in some kind of action.
My question is were you required to join them, did you see that as part of your work?
No one ordered you to join  Shuga and so on?
Were you ordered to guard Bulelwa's body?
Did you respond to the SDU call?
The whistle call, do you mean?
Dit you respond to the whistle?
Which was calling SDU members to go and ...
Yes, I responded to the whistle call.
Was guarding Bulelwa's body, part of your duty in the SDU?
Was the capturing of these boys with Sonti, part of that?
Yes, it was part of the defence.
The capturing of these boys, how was that going to protect the community?
Capturing those boys will be protecting the community in this way - these boys had killed members of the community of Muleleki Extension 2.
Another point of fact was about the infiltration of the third force, because they called themselves ANC Youth League but in actions, they were actually not ANC Youth League.
Are you saying that they called themselves members of the ANC Youth League, but their conduct was inconsistent with members of the ANC Youth League?
And the weapons that they had in their possession, were weapons that were being used by the Police.
What did that indicate the fact that the weapons were similar to the Police's?
That indicated some collaboration of some kind between them and the third force.
Are you suggesting that because they carried firearms similar to those carried by the Police, therefore they were working hand in hand with the Police?
That is what I am saying.
Do you know how they got - did you personally see anyone of them carrying a weapon similar to the one used by the Police?
I do hope that in my statement that is clear, that when we searched them, the other three, we realised the pistol.
What kind of a pistol was this?
It was a 9, the one that Police use.
Did you ask him how he got hold of that short 9?
Could he not have stolen it from the Police?
Do you have any other evidence that the weapons they had, were similar to those of the Police, besides this 9 mm?
No, I don't have any other evidence to that effect, except for what I have already told you.
Did you hear from your comrades in the SDU about them having firearms similar to those of the Police?
I had heard from comrade Sonti when they were going to kill the Majosi.
He said he arrived to him with Majosi's cousin, passing.
What did he say about firearms?
These persons, from your information, had been carrying these firearms which were used by the Police even before Bulelwa and Blanko were killed?
And prior to Blanko and Bulelwa being killed, they had already demonstrated conduct which you believe was inconsistent with the members of the ANC Youth League?

Before Blanko and Bulelwa were killed, you already have seen that their conduct was not consistent, or was not the way the ANC Youth League members carried themselves.  They were not killed prior to the death of Bulelwa and Blanko?
There is one, the one that made them to disassociate themselves with us because we tried to stop them from their conduct.
Is that the reason why they were not killed before?
What are you suggesting, I am asking you whether is there any reason why they were not killed prior to the death of Bulelwa and Blanko?
We did not have any proof before that.
To catch them red-handed you know, because in Blanko's case, we also realised some boxes of cigarettes which were proof to us.
About proof that of something that they had in hand from where they attacked.

You see, I am asking you and you have told us that prior to the death of Blanko and Bulelwa, you believed that the persons who were captured and killed, were engaged in a conduct which was inconsistent with members of the ANC Youth League.

What I want to find out from you is if that were to be the case, and I think you have told us, we know that they had been involved in the killing of Majosi for example, was a member of the South African Communist Party we were told, they were also involved, we were told in the hijacking of a bakkie for a Mr Makanya for example.
	What we want to find out from you, if you had all of this information, why were they not killed prior to the death of Bulelwa and Blanko?
That question is difficult.  It is a quite difficult question.
Now Blanko was the Chairman of SDU, is that correct?

What did his death mean to you in relation to the protection of the community?
	Did you understand my question?
No, I don't understand your question.
Blanko was the Chairman of SDU?
There was evidence from Oscar that he was killed by ANC Youth League?
Was his death connected with the protection of the community?
You mean the death of Blanko?  It was not related, they were attacking the community.
No, you don't understand me.  Let me put it this way ...
You see, we were protecting the community.
Yes, I know.  Was the killing of SDU members, going to expose the community to the ANC Youth League?
Now, did you benefit anything from capturing those boys?
I have no further questions Mr Chairman.
Thank you Chairperson.  I have no questions.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Ndabe, you say Pinky's mother described how her son was dressed, did I understand you correctly?
Now, was her son one of those whom you captured?
Those are the ones we captured, three of them, he was one of the three in other words.
Now, do you I mean today, not at that stage, today, do you know who is Pinky's mother in other words, her name or her surname?
I wouldn't say that, I don't know the surname, because the husband we refer to him as Mokoena if I am not mistaken.
So, the mother we are talking about is Mrs Mokoena, is that so?
I don't want to confirm that.
At the stage when you were capturing these, the three boys you captured, did you know what will eventually happen with them?
But one of the applicants yesterday said that if a person kills, that person would be killed.  Did you hear that applicant saying so?
I wouldn't say I heard this.
And then the killing of these youth, to me appears as if it was an avenge for the death of Blanko, you were retaliating because they killed Blanko.  What do you say about that?
Okay, thank you Mr Chairperson, no further questions.
Mr Ndabe, this Pinky, was she a friend of Bulelwa's?
No, that is not the one, that is not the Pinky.
Mr Ndabe, before the Youth League separated themselves from you, that is the SDU, you used to patrol together?

Just explain to us, we know from the evidence we have heard that operators used to carry guns and those would be issued by the Commander Regional or Central, but they used to carry guns and in this respect AK47's, is that so?
Were the members of the Youth League, when they joined you, also being issued with that type of weaponry?
We are told that the operators were trained, now when you were patrolling or rather let's put it this way, members of the Youth League who joined you, were they trained?

You have referred to incidents of shootings, but it would appear that whilst this ensued nobody (indistinct) injured in the process and since your members that is the SDU were trained, they couldn't shoot straight could they?
You happen to know Pinky's mother, she took the trouble to describe the clothing of her son.  Would you know that the son was one of the victims that is one of the people who died?
To date, from 1993 December, 7, have you endeavoured to find out who this son was?
You were probably vindicated that you had achieved your objective in killing the victims in the process of protecting the community, are you saying that to us?
That is not what I am saying.
We know, or rather let's ask you, do you regard the families of the victims as part of the community which you tried to protect?

And it would be human nature that if one of the members of the community and let's confine ourselves to Muleleki, that if something befalls that family, you would find out what happened from that family, wouldn't that be so?

These members of the African National Congress Youth League, were not a menace to only the other members of the community, but their families too were threatened, would I be right if I think along those lines?
But we should accept that when you protected the community of Muleleki, the members of the victims, the families of the victims where you were trying to protect them as well, should we accept that?
Thank you Chairperson, I've got no further questions.
The identity of Pinky's mother, would her first name be Alphina?
I don't know the name, she is also present here.  I may ask her if you so wish that she may identify herself.

I just want to make sure because we have information that Mrs Alphina Mokati says that she met up with you and at that stage, there was also Mrs Constance Sindesi was also there and that you were asked about their children, and that you answered only Mrs Mokati, Alphina Mokati, told her that her child was indeed in the shack.
	Were there two women that asked you, is that correct?
Then if that is so, then the Youth's name would have been Isaac Mogadi if the woman ...
I think she said something to that effect.
I understand that you fell tired and you went to your house to sleep? ... (tape ends) ... that you were going home?
I did not report to anyone.
Is there a reason why you did not report that you were going home?
I just thought that I am sneaking out to go and sleep, and I will quickly coming back.
Did anyone see you leaving?  There were many people there I suppose?
Yes, there were many people, Defence, with other people of the community.
Yes, but did anyone see you leave?
The person who saw me was one of the civilians in F because I passed by their house.
And could any other member of the SDU who wanted to do what you did, have done that just go home and sleep?
Well, if you are able to do it, is there any reason why the others could not have done that?  Did you get the question?
I heard your question, I am still thinking.  I suppose no, I wouldn't know.
No, I mean you were present at the scene and you were able to go home, sleep until the afternoon.

And thereby avoid going to the veld where the persons were killed.  Is there anything which could have prevented the other members of the SDU from doing what you did - simple go home, sleep until the afternoon?
I wasn't avoiding whether I did not also know whether people will be killed or not.  I was there at the corpse, I thought people would explain it to the community as to what was happening.

Yes, in other words you assumed that because they have now been brought to the community, the community will then have to decide what to do with them, your duties as an SDU had come to an end, you can simply go and sleep?
I had to go and sleep because it was in the morning.
There was nothing which - the other members of the SDU's could have done the same, couldn't they?
Some had to keep guard, they had to be there.  It wasn't easy for them because there was another group that was released at night to go and sleep.

I understand that, you see you told us that as far as you understood the situation, because the people had been brought to the community, the community was then to decide their fate, you were free to go and sleep, that is what you told us, right?
So I am saying, any other member of the SDU could have done the same, they could have gone to their respective homes and slept the rest of the day?
Yes.  Were you aware of a rumour that the members of the ANC Youth League were out to kill members of the SDU?
They were planning on killing members of the SDU?
I wouldn't confirm that because we are still trying to arrange meetings where we could discuss these matters.
Yes, but did you hear the rumour though that members of the ANC Youth League ...
The rumours, yes, I heard them.
That they wanted to kill the members of the SDU?
What steps if any, were taken by the members of the SDU to protect themselves against such a planned killing?

We did not try to protect ourselves, all that we did was to write a letter, we send Vuzi Mthembu to write a letter to them so we arranged a meeting and we discussed this matter, but that was to no avail.
Blanko was a member of the SDU?
Bulelwa would sympathise with the SDU?
She was the community member and the street committee in the Civic.
Did she sympathise with the SDU?
This is how Civic is structured in the SDU.
I am not talking about the Civic, I am talking about Bulelwa.  Did she sympathise with the SDU?
Now, the killing of Blanko who was a member of the SDU, did it not suggest to you that the ANC Youth League was now carrying out their plan of action to kill SDU members?
Mr Ndabe, comrade Motlokwa recognised at least one person, that is Tusaneng who were attacking the house of Blanko, would I be right?
No, he said Tusaneng and Vips are the ones that he saw.  Otherwise they were quite many in number.
Yes, that is what I am saying, and did he tell you about the looting of tuckshop of Blanko?

He only told us about the shooting and we heard as well and we ran in the opposite direction, and at the time when we were running towards Blanko, that is when Nxeba Sonti was there as well, we found that their house was burning fiercely and Blanko was sitting on the chair, helplessly.
You mentioned in your evidence that you met members of the Youth League with cartons of cigarettes, did I hear you correctly?

Yes.  They did not meet with me, or I did not meet them, but the man that left first in the company of Oscar, following the car that was going to fetch the corpse, then they met because he told us that those boys were coming out from another shack and shooting and insulting and they chased after them and they went to this tall grass and this boys now appeared with the cigarettes in their possession, and tin stuff.
Now, whilst you were told about the tin stuff and the cigarette cartons, wouldn't you say they are the same even if obtained from any other shop?
But your comrades, the SDU's did they use this finding of tin stuff and cigarette cartons that these were part of Blanko's merchandise?

Because you know I want an explanation, I don't understand this that up to you, nobody has mentioned that Blanko's tuckshop was looted but there was merely a suggestion, but nobody said he saw it.
	They said that came from Blanko's shop because when they killed him, that for instance we saw Tusaneng, for instance, because this is a person we all know was positively identified that we sat Tusaneng helping himself to the merchandise, but when people are met with some tin stuff and all that, then some conclusion is made that these are the people who had attacked Blanko and taken some of his stock.  Could you probably shed some light that we understand the whole thing that happened the 6th of December 1993, are you able to do that?

I am certain that the tuckshop that they attacked, had tin stuff, although I am not sure as to how much stock there was, since Blanko was so helpful in the community of F as far as food is concerned.
	When you got there to the tuckshop the shelves were empty suddenly, the fridge itself was empty.
When I asked you about this Pinky you gave the indication or you left the impression that you know the Pinky who was with Bulelwa when she was shot, did you know her well?
No.  Even Bulelwa herself, I did not know her.
Do you know the Pinky that was with Bulelwa when she was shot?
How do you know that it is not the same Pinky?
The one that I am talking about is younger and is this mother's child, it is a school child.
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Ndabe, is it correct that the SDU procedure during patrols was that you would have shifts, day and night shifts?
And is it correct therefore that people who were doing night shift were expected to go home?

Wait a minute, doing night shift where?  We know that the patrols were conducted during the day and at night.  Are you suggesting that individuals who worked the night shift in their places of employment ...
Is it the SDU would patrol during the day?

I am suggesting that the SDU members who were doing night patrol or night duty in the SDU activity, were expected, yes who patrolled.  By patrolling Mr Chairman, I include for example looking after Bulelwa's corpse through out the night, that was patrolling.

I understand that but I wanted to make sure that I understand the question is whether - you are talking about a patrol that members of the SDU who would patrol during the day are allowed to rest in the evening and those who patrol during the night, are allowed to rest during the day, subject to the whistle blowing?
	Did you hear the question?
The question is SDU members who did the day shift, were expected to rest at night and those who did night shift were expected to rest during the day?
On that day when you responded to the whistle, you have told us that you looked after Bulelwa's body through out the night, is that so?
Were you therefore expected to rest afterwards during the day?
Yes, I was expected to go and rest.
Would members who had not done the night shift, be expected to rest as well?
It was expected for them to be on duty.

Thank you Mr Ndabe, you may return to your seat.
WITNESS EXCUSED
Mr Chairman, I call Themba Christopher Mtshali.
Mr Mtshali, what language are you going to speak?
Thank you Mr Chair.  How old are you?
How far did you go at school?
I went as far as standard 7.
In December 1993, did you live at Muleleki?
The SDU - you were a patroller and an operator?
In the killings of December 1993, which we are talking about here, tell us about the role that you played, if you did participate.
Tell us about what you did.
In the morning we were sent by Comrade Commander Nxeba Ndondolo.
Where were you when he sent you?
Tell us how did it come about that you went to Bulelwa's body?  Start from there?
Why did you go to her body?

Let me just go back a little bit.  On the 6th at round about eight o'clock, we heard gun fire.  As we were surprised we heard a whistle being blown.
	I then left as a member of the Self Defence Unit, carried my stick and brought my blanket along, rushing to the scene where the whistle was being blown.
	On my arrival I found some comrades even though I did not see them all.  I went to the place where the whistle was being blown, that was Block F.
On arrival I found some comrades and a corpse laying on the road, a female corpse.
There was also comrade Buthelezi who said to me comrade, we don't want a person wearing a blanket here.  I did not object to that and when I went back, there were two of us comrades wearing blankets.
Who were those whom you met?
I went back to my place and continued to sleep.
I slept and in the morning I woke up, went back to the place where neighbours were rushing to.   I found that the corpse that was laying there yesterday, was still there.
The whole community had gathered there, discussing this issue.  I then heard that there is also another one who was shot at night in Block E.
I then went to Block E to see what damage had been caused there.
On arrival there was a comrade who was burnt in the house.
He was sitting on a chair and that was comrade Blanko.
I then heard people saying he was killed by the Youth.
I went back to Block F to Bulelwa's corpse.  As I was still standing there, comrade Shongwe and Lefu came to me.

And they said comrade Ndondolo instructed us to go and fetch another boy who is alleged to be involved.  There are questions that he wanted to pose to him.
	We then left.

On arrival we asked and we found his mother and his sister, that is Mavuso.  His mother said yes, he is here, he is asleep.  We indicated that we were sent by comrade Commander because he wanted to ask him questions.
We then woke him up and he did.
Did you go to where he was sleeping to wake him up yourselves?

We went back to Bulelwa's corpse.  When we arrived there, it was indicated to the community that this is the person and it was indicated that we should take him to the shack, and this instruction came from comrade Commander.
Yes, that is the first one, the one that was nearer to Bulelwa's corpse.
I then went to the community and attended the meeting that was being held there.  Here I think I will stop.
Did you go to the place where they were killed?
What was the community talking about near Bulelwa's body?
The community was discussing crime and violence.
How was the mood of the community members?
Can you estimate how many people were there?
I can estimate them to be in excess of 100.
Do you know from which area they came?
Those that I knew, were from Block F, but certainly the people there were not only from Block F.
Was that meeting a formal meeting, chaired or was it informal?
The meeting had proceeded when I arrived there, and therefore I do not know who chaired the meeting.
Was there anything at that meeting said about the death of Blanko and Bulelwa?
No, I didn't hear anything to that effect.
Were their deaths the subject of that meeting?
What I still remember is that they had long been waiting for the Peace Committee vehicle, and it hadn't shown up because the corpse had been laying there since the previous night.
Why were you involved in removing Mavuso from his home?
I followed the instructions that comrade Commander gave to me.
Was that your duty in the SDU?
Yes, it is part of my duty that I carry out what instructions he gave me.
SDU was maintaining peace within the community, is that correct?
Was the removal of Mavuso part of that?

Yes, I can say so sir because even when I say when I arrived there, the meeting had already proceeded, I heard that the community was complaining that someone had been shot at night, and now other comrades had indicated that Mavuso is also part of what happened the previous night.
Did you benefit anything from your participation in this matter?
There is nothing that I benefitted from this.
I have no further questions Mr Chairman.
Thank you Chairperson.  The meeting that you are talking about, is it a meeting that was addressed by Mashinini?
I would not so no comrade, because I don't even know Mashinini, whether he was there or not, I have never seen him.
And the meeting you are talking about, was it a meeting nearby Bulelwa's corpse?
Did you attend any meeting at Blanko's place?
No, I didn't stay at Blanko's place.  I just went there to establish the damage and then I went back.
Thank you, no further questions Judge Ngcobo.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Mtshali, it would seem the meeting we are talking about, in actual fact was not a meeting, but it was the people who had gathered there after hearing a whistle being blown, am I correct?
In other words there was no specific Chairperson, specific speakers who were addressing the people, only some SDU members addressed the people who had gathered there to pay their respects?
I would ask the Chairperson to indicate exactly which meeting is he talking about.  The one at Bulelwa's place or Bulelwa's body or something else, another meeting?

I have already explained that in the first day we were sent away and I went back to sleep.   On the second day I came back and they were discussing the fact that they were waiting for the Peace Committee vehicle for a very long time, and it had now shown up.

Mr Mtshali, I heard you saying you followed the instructions which were given by the Commander, but now when you look back and look at the deeds which you committed, people have lost their dear ones, children have lost their parents, is there anything you would like to say in that regard?
There is nothing that I would like to say.
Are you saying you are not sorry for what happened, you don't have any remorse over what you did?
Thank you, no further questions Mr Chairperson.
Mr Mtshali, you said that you got the instructions from the Commander to go and fetch Mavuso to answer to questions.  Is that correct?

Then you said when you arrived, you went back to the corpse, and when you arrived it was indicated to the community that this is the person, and then he was taken to the shack and then you went back to the community and attended the meeting that was being held there, is that correct?
My question is whether you were present when any questions were asked of Mavuso?  Did the Commander ask questions of Mavuso?
He presented Mr Mavuso to the public and on doing so, he indicated that the boys from the shack said Mavuso was also part of it.  I was not there when he was being questioned.
You were still there when he was taken to the shack?
Yes, I was there when he was taken to the shack, but I then went back to the community.
So while you were there, Mavuso did not address the community?
May I take you to another meeting in Block F.  You heard the evidence of some of your co-applicants, your comrades, that a new SDU was to be established in Block F, some time before this incident.
Did the community accept the new SDU?

It was said this SDU was going to be in charge of Block F.  But those who were present said they were not enough SDU members in Block F, and therefore they need their own Self Defence Unit because Block F is facing Zonkezizwe which place is an Inkatha area.
And those present, agreed to that?
I wouldn't say, but I never heard any objection.
From no one?  Did no one object?
She was told to keep quiet.  When it was time for them to indicate to the community that every household should donate R50-00 to buy shovels.
Did she object to the R50-00 or what did she object to, why was she told to keep quiet, what did she say?
She said that it is not possible for another Self Defence Unit to be formed when there is already one existing.
Mr Mtshali, did you hear her say that or did you hear that in evidence from someone else who sat here yesterday and during the week?
I personally heard her say that.
Would that not have been construed as an objection?
Those who were at the meeting showed not to be in agreement with what she was saying and it transpired that she was, yes, objecting to what had already been said.
How old was Bulelwa, do you have any idea?
I would say she was somewhere around 22 years.
Even though I cannot be sure, it looks like she was not a member of the Youth League.
Was she an enemy to the Youth League?
I am not sure about that Mr Chairperson.
No further questions thank you, Chairman.

Thank you Chairperson.  Mr Mtshali, I just want to know the number that is how many members comprised the SDU and in this respect, let's just confine ourselves to those who were patrolling Muleleki Section as a whole A to E or F, how many members, how many were you in the SDU?
There were many of us Mr Chairperson.   I can estimate to around 45 upwards.
Thank you Mr Chairperson, I've got no further questions.
You told us that when you first arrived at the spot where Bulelwa's body was laying, you were told that people with blankets were not welcomed.
And you said Buthelezi said this?
Is this Buthelezi who was subsequently killed?
Do you know why Buthelezi would have said that people with blankets are not welcomed there?
It is because he was not part of the ANC struggle.
Are you saying that he was not a full member of the ANC?
Yes, that is correct.  He was not a full member of the ANC.  Will you please repeat your question?
He was not a full member of the ANC?

It is because one day there was a truck, a paraffin truck that was hijacked by the Youth and they took this truck to a place between Block F and Block E.
	And when I got out of the house, I saw the community running with buckets, water buckets and plastic water containers.  When I rushed there to establish what was happening, I saw on the tar road separating Block F and Block E, I saw this truck and that is where the community had gathered.
	The route came from comrade Buthelezi.  He too was standing outside in the street.  When I went to him, that is when I could actually see what this truck was all about.  I then said to comrade, when I realised that people were pushing that, I realised that people were differing on this thing.
	When I got there, it was a paraffin truck.  I then asked him is it the right thing to do and he said this thing belongs to the Boers, you don't have to worry.  I then went back into the house.  	That is why I got assurance that he was not an ANC member because he was supposed to call the youth to order when they made mistakes, because that paraffin was going to help us.
Any other reason why you suggested that Buthelezi wasn't a full member of the ANC?

Yes, I do have another reason.  That refers to the formation of the Self Defence Unit when there was one already in existence.  This is also something that I concluded will create a problem in the community.
No, I don't have any other reason Mr Chairperson.
As I understand from you, the decision to form the new SDU was taken by the residents of F Section, because I gathered from you that there weren't many members of the SDU there?  Is that right?
Do you therefore consider the other residents of Block F who decided to form the new SDU, not to be full members of the ANC?
They were members of the ANC.
Notwithstanding the fact that they had decided to form a new SDU?
They were instructed by Buthelezi because these were his ideas of forming the new SDU.  I would say they agreed to being forced to submit.
Were there many members of the SDU at Block F?
There were two SDU members in Block F, among those who have applied here.
Were those two members enough to patrol the whole of Block F?
When you went to Blanko's house, were there many people who had gathered there?
Were there any members of the SDU present?
You did not stay there, you just went there to observe the damage and then you returned to where Bulelwa's body was?
Was there any specific reason why you didn't stay there at Blanko's house?
Just before you left Blanko's house to return to where Bulelwa's body was, did you hear what people were talking about there?
But you couldn't hear what they were talking about?
Yes, you then returned to the spot where Bulelwa's body was?
There people were talking about the unrest and crime?
You could hear people talking about that?
Was there any suggestion as to who had killed Bulelwa, at the meeting?
It was said the Youth was involved.
When you returned to the spot where Bulelwa was, you were not longer wearing the blanket, were you?
I still had my blanket on.

What made you to go, to leave the spot in the first place?  Well, you told us that when you arrived there Buthelezi said that people who were wearing blankets were not welcomed here and you left, right?
But you returned later wearing the same blanket?
Why did you leave in the first place?
I came back the following day Chairperson, seeing other comrades who were wearing blankets there as well.
Was there any suggestion at all that Bulelwa had been killed by the members of the SDU?
What is it that you did not know?
I did not know that Bulelwa was killed by the SDU members.

There were rumours and talks, are there rumours that you came across to the effect that Bulelwa was killed by SDU comrades?  Is there any reason why you did not go to the veld where the people were killed?
Before you left, did you say that you from where you had been, that is at the spot where Bulelwa's body was, you returned to your house?
Yes, that is correct.  When the corpse was being taken shortly after the car had arrived to pick the corpse up.
When the body was removed, were the deceased still in the shacks, locked up in the shacks?

Which deceased are you referring to Chairperson?  The children who were killed in the veld, yes, I would say so even though I was not there personally, I was in the community, guarding over Bulelwa's body.
Did you see the deceased being removed from this shack to another shack?
Did you know what was going to happen to these persons?
Did you ever think what was going to happen?
No, I did not because I did not know what decision the Commander will take.
As a member of the SDU, did you consider it necessary that you must be present to hear what the Commander was going to say often concerning the fate of these individuals?
Yes, I did but the Commander did not instruct me to be part of the group that left.
Did you expect the Commander to call you to come?
Were the people who went with the deceased to the veld, called by the Commander?
Did he call them by their names?
I am not sure about that.
Were you present when he called them?
No, I was not present, that is why I am saying how he actually called them, because I was not present.
How do you know that they were called by him?
He is the one who was in charge of the organisation, he was the one who was making orders.
But you see as I understand your evidence, you said that the people who went there, were people who were called by the Commander to go there.
But you didn't go there because the Commander didn't call you?
And I am asking you how do you know  that these are the persons - were called by the Commander to go to the place where the deceased were killed?
I have already indicated that I am not sure because I was not present.
Before you left, did you tell the Commander that you were now leaving?
No, I did not tell him.
How was the Commander going to find you, if you leave without you telling him?
It is because he was not at Bulelwa's corpse.  I went back to my place when the community started dispersing.
Yes, I understand that.  You expected that the Commander would call you, but how was he going to call you if you leave without telling him that you are now going to your house as a member of the SDU?
Would you please repeat your question Mr Chairperson?
You were a member of the SDU, you were waiting for the Commander Nxeba Ndondolo to give an instruction to go to the veld with the rest?

What I am asking you now is because you had just left without informing him that you were now leaving, I am now leaving, going back home, how was he supposed to know where you were if he wanted to use you?
He did not know where I resided.
Thank you Mr Chairman.  In the SDU, was a member required to patrol the area where he was living in or would a member patrol even other Blocks where he did not live?
A member would not patrol in an area where they did not reside, they patrolled all the Blocks.
So at the time Buthelezi called that meeting, Block F was patrolled but not by members of F Block?

Yes, that is correct.  It was being patrolled by members of the Self Defence Unit, the one that patrolled Muleleki, the whole of Muleleki.  Such that this is how I realised that there was going to be conflict if another SDU is formed where there is this one existing already.
So Buthelezi wanted  F people to patrol F Block?
Which was not policy of the SDU?  That was not the policy of the SDU?
And then you say but the SDU members who lived in F, were few, it was only you and another person?
You were in Block F, but you didn't patrol Block F, is that right?
Yes, I was in Block F, but I was patrolling the whole 6, including Block F.
You mentioned I think it is that there were approximately 45 members of the SDU?
Of this 45, only two stayed in Block F?
Yes, thank you.  Mr Mtshali, you may return to your seat.
I don't know Chairperson, whether I can have my request.
Do you want to discuss that with your counsel first?
No.  I can also present this here if you can give me the right to show.

Thank you Chairperson.  I would request families of those who lost their children, please forgive me.  I did not like what happened.  The members of the Self Defence Units did not like this, we are therefore applying for amnesty.  We will meet with our counsel so that we can meet with the next of kin, especially the women, Mavuso's mother in particular.  Thank you very much.

Thank you Mr Mtshali.  You may return to your seat.
WITNESS EXCUSED
	We will take the tea adjournment now, we will return at half past eleven.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION
Mr Madasa, have you now had enough time to consult with your witnesses?
Okay very well, shall we start?
Mr Chairperson, may I call Bulelwa Ndwane, as a witness for the applicants?
Good morning Ma'am, what language are you going to speak?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  In 1993, where were you staying?
I stayed at Muleleki, Extension 2, Block F.
I know them because they were members of SDU patrolling at Muleleki.
Do you know which areas in Muleleki they patrolled?
Which areas?  Did you belong to any organisation?
Sorry, may we just hear which areas they were patrolling?
I was a member of the ANC.
She said they patrolled A to F.  Did the SDU patrol all the Blocks in Muleleki?
Yes, they patrolled all the Blocks.
During that time, did you belong to any structure?
Yes, I was an ordinary member.
Did you belong to a street committee or civic or women's league?
No, I was not a member of the street committee, but I would go to the women's league meetings.  I was not a member of the women's league, but I did attend the meetings.
Was the community at F in December 1993, satisfied with the patrols of the SDU to your knowledge?
According to my knowledge, or I never heard anyone complaining about the SDU or the way they patrolled.
Now, is there a child who stayed with you at your place who belonged to an organisation?
Yes, I stayed with my youngest sister, Nomfundu Ndwane, she was a member of the ANC Youth League, she was the Secretary of the ANC Youth League.
Did you know Bulelwa who is now deceased?

We stayed in the same Block, Block F.  She was a member of the street committee at that time in our street.  Maybe I am mistaken at the moment, perhaps the street next to ours, maybe not our street per se but maybe the next street.
As far as you know, did he have a good relationship with the SDU?

She had no problem with the SDU, they were just people to her, members of the community.  Even with the Youth League, I wouldn't say she had a problem.  It is just that I am not sure about the members of the Youth League, therefore I can't really say that she had a problem with the Youth League.
You are aware that Bulelwa was killed?
The day before she was killed, is there anything - was there any meeting called by the Youth League if he there has, tell us about that?
Firstly, how do you know that the Youth League called a meeting on that day?
Two comrades came to my house, members of the Youth League, they wanted Nomfundu.
Yes?  Sorry, do you know their names?
No, I do not know them.  When they arrived, they asked where Nomfundu was.  I told them that she went to Nxlapo Section where she was visiting.
They left a message for me to tell her that there was a meeting at eight o'clock at a place where we called the FNB.
On the Sunday, they came back at about three o'clock.
Fortunately that is when Nomfundu arrived, coming from Nxlapo.  They spoke to her outside, because that is where they met each other.
As she was going inside, I asked her if she had gotten her message that there was going to be a meeting.  She said yes, there was going to be a meeting at eight o'clock in the evening.
In the evening Nomfundu prepared to go to the meeting.   After about 15 minutes after she left, she came back.  15 Minutes elapsed after she had left, and she came back.
When I asked her how the meeting was, she said she did not know what was going on, she said she was asked to go home and wear her tracksuit and tackies.
When I wanted to know exactly what was going on, she said that the SDU had called them to Block E.

I said to her as she was not the only female member of the Youth League, I asked her to stay at home and lock the door, she must only open for me I said.  I said I am going to a lady who has children who are members of the Youth League.
	I didn't understand.
I said I am going to a lady who has children who were also members of the ANC Youth League.

I got to this lady, I said to her I was actually looking for her daughters.  I said to them that my sister could not go with them, I had a problem because it was at night.
	When I got there there was a group of men, when I was about to knock at the door, they ran away.  It was the Youth League.
I went inside, I told this lady that my sister could not go to this meeting because it was at night, and she was a girl.

Whilst I was speaking to this lady, a certain young man knocked on the door.
	He asked for a key from this lady.  I saw this young man, I don't know if I should divulge his name.
This lady gave him the key.  After I had spoken to this lady, I then said I am leaving.  On the way back home, I came across these young men.
One of them said I told you that you were hurrying this thing up.
I greeted them, after I did that, I asked them what is going on here men, I said.  They said no Ma'am, nothing is going on.
Were there any girls amongst them?
No, it was just young men.
I then proceeded on my way home.
I got there and I slept.
Did Nomfundu go to the meeting?
And then the following day was Bulelwa's death?
In the morning the next day, I just heard a noise.  Somebody then knocked on my door after the noise.
This lady asked me if I had heard that the gun shots that were fired the previous night, they were used on Bulelwa.
After I heard I left to go to the other women that were on my street, I told them that we should go and see where Bulelwa was killed.
Yes, I did go.  Her corpse was there on the road, but it was covered.  There were men standing around.
Yes, the community did gather.  Not a lot of people, there was not even 100 people, just a group.
Did you remain there at Bulelwa's corpse?

We stood there, listened.  There were already some comrades there.  I remember that we spoke to comrade Buthelezi.  He said that we have found Bulelwa's corpse.
	He said that they had not slept the whole night, just looking over the corpse.
After that, we went back home because I was preparing to go to work.
Do you know of the meeting that was called by Buthelezi at F?
I don't know what the meeting was about because he called a lot of meetings as he ...
Okay, let me ask you this, do you know Buthelezi?
Did he belong to any organisation?
He was a member of the Block, Block F.
Did he belong to a political organisation?
I wouldn't know, I wasn't used to the man.
Do you know that a meeting was called to form a new SDU for Block F by Buthelezi?
Did you go to that meeting?
Were you told why the meeting was called?
We were told that a new SDU was going to be formed.
Who told you that, who called the meeting?

I couldn't be sure about that, I don't know who the Chairperson of the meeting was, however comrade Buthelezi is one of the people who said that this meeting has been called, because they were going to form a new SDU.
Did Bulelwa talk at that meeting?
She asked if it was important for a new SDU to be formed where there was a SDU existing at the time.
I am not sure how she answered.
Was money collected at that meeting?
No, money was not collected, however, R50-00 per house was meant to be collected.
Had Bulelwa asked why is it necessary to form a new SDU when there was one in existence?
Yes, I heard her ask that.
Did anyone respond to her question?
Certainly there should have been somebody who answered.  However, I was not interested in listening to the answer.
What did you do after the question, did you leave the meeting?
I did not leave the meeting, but I was not interested.
Why did you loose interest in the matter?
The reason why I lost interest, is because a new SDU was going to be formed, meanwhile there was one in existence.  Also I was not happy about the fact that we had to pop out R50-00 each house.
Did you want the new SDU to be formed?
I was not interested in the new SDU.
Were you not interested to know why it was necessary to form a new SDU?

The reason why I was not interested in the reasoning, is because I stayed with someone who was a member of the ANC Youth League.  The reason why I was unhappy was because I found out that they wanted to also use girls in this new SDU that they were forming.
At what stage of meeting did you hear that the purpose of the meeting was to form a new SDU?
Could you repeat the question please.
At what stage did you hear that the purpose of the meeting was to form the new SDU?
After they had already said, however I had already heard that the ANC Youth League wanted to form a new SDU because they were saying that their parents were being attacked.
So before you went to the meeting, you knew that the meeting was going to be about the forming of a new SDU?

As I have already said, I stayed with someone who was a member of the ANC Youth League.  She would complain to me of some things, she would tell me that she is a member of the ANC Youth League but she did not know what was going on.
	She was not clear of what was going on.  However, I later found out that they used to hide information from her because the ANC Youth League said I am quite close to the SDU.
Prior to going to the meeting, did you know that the meeting was going to discuss the formation of a new SDU?
You only learnt that for the first time at the meeting?
I could put it like that.
You nevertheless continued to remain at the meeting?
I did not stay until the end of the meeting.
You were present when Bulelwa asked why it was necessary to form a new SDU?
After she had asked the question, you then suddenly lost interest in the meeting?
I lost interest, I was disinterested from the time they even mentioned that they were forming a new SDU.
You didn't bother to find out why it was necessary to form a new SDU?
You yourself was not in favour of the formation of the new SDU?
I did not agree with that because I knew that there was a SDU already in existence.
You were not in favour of the formation of the new SDU?
Was the community supportive of the new formation of the SDU?
No, they did not support that idea.  However ...
Did you hear anyone at the meeting speaking in favour of the formation of the SDU?
This different view that you are talking about, what are they?
In a meeting everybody views, or everybody says what they think, gives their viewpoint.
Then how do you know that the people were not in favour of the establishment of the new SDU?
Sorry Mr Chairman, the witness with due respect has told the Committee that at that meeting there was division as to the formation of the new SDU, that is what she said.
But she said no one spoke against that, no one spoke in favour of the SDU?
She said there was division amongst the people who attended.
I want to know what division, what were the people saying?
Some of the people were against the SDU, as Bulelwa said or asked if it was necessary to form a new SDU, she asked if this was not going to cause conflict.
I have no further questions Your Worship.
Thank you Chairperson.  Ms Ndwane, is it correct that Bulelwa and Buthelezi were staying in Block F?
And both of them were leaders in the community structures in Block F?
Now in that meeting that you are talking about, was there at any stage where some people were not allowed to talk because they are women?
I am not sure about that.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Ndwane, where is this Nomfundu Ndwane today?
She is around, but not here.
No, she is not here in the hall.
And then since when was she a member of the ANC Youth League, when did she become a member of the ANC Youth League?
She became a member of the ANC Youth League after being recruited by other girls who were staying at Block F, who were already members of the ANC Youth League.
In 1993, before December.  I can't remember, at the time of this incident, it hadn't been a long time since she had joined.
Could it be July or August or September, can you estimate a month?
I think it was around July, but I am not sure.

We have heard from applicants that there were generally complaints about the Youth League, the ANC Youth League, among others that the Youth League was hijacking cars, looting tuckshops - were you also aware of that since you were staying with a member of the ANC Youth League?
As I have already said, Nomfundu was not clear of certain issues.  She did not tell me of such.

So you are saying you were not aware that generally in the community you were staying in, people were being killed, cars hijacked and spaza shops looted.  Let me separate my question were you aware of those rumours or were you not aware?
Yes, I have heard such rumours.
You heard them from the community, is that correct?
Did you also hear that the people who were suspected of those deeds, were members of the ANC Youth League?
I am not sure exactly who was guilty.  We would hear that bakeries are being looted, tuckshops, people had been killed, but nobody ever said that all that was being done by the ANC Youth League.
Did you hear about the death of Majosi who was the member of the South African Communist Party?
Did you hear that the Youth League apologised for his death?
No.  I did not hear that.
Did your sister Nomfundu never discuss the issue with you?
As I have already said, Nomfundu would go to the meetings.  She was elected as a Secretary, but she never even had a book for the minutes of the meeting.

But exactly as a Secretary, she was supposed to be in a better position to know more about the activities of the ANC Youth League than an ordinary member, she was in the Executive.  What is your comment about that?

Yes, I agree but she did not like what she was doing.  But as a mother or sort of a mother for her, I said to her she should be a member of the ANC Youth League, because other children were as well.
	I did not particularly see a reason why she shouldn't join the ANC Youth League, so I encouraged her.
I heard you saying that you were suspected or you were regarded as being close to the SDU's, am I correct?
Yes, they suspected that I was Nxeba Sonti's sister.  They perceived me as Nxeba Sonti's sister.
Were you close to the SDU's?
I was used to them.  Some of them were my home boys.
Were you aware of the differences or problems the SDU's had with the ANC Youth League?
No, I was not aware.  Because even if we would meet, we would not talk about problems of the SDU or ANC Youth League, we just talked about personal things.

Some of the applicants told this Committee that the SDU's attempted on several occasions, to hold a meeting with the ANC Youth League, but that the League was avoiding such a meeting.  Are you aware of that or not?

I have no knowledge of such, the only thing I know is that Nomfundu was told to get dressed and go to a meeting called by the ANC Youth League at Block E.
	But because she did not go to the meeting, I never did find out why they were called to the meeting.  I am not aware about other meetings.
You said the meeting was supposed to be held at a place you call FNB, where is this place in relation to the shack where Bulelwa was staying?
It is not too far, it is quite close.
You said Thokozani Buthelezi,  that is Mr Buthelezi's son, asked for a key, what key was that?
I don't know what key this was.  However, I thought that it was a key that belonged to a shack that was opposite this lady where I was, where these children would gather regularly.
From the day Bulelwa asked questions at the meeting about the formation of the new SDU, how many days thereafter was she killed?
Were there many days, a week or less than a week?
I don't want to lie, I can't remember.
You said you were woken up by somebody in the morning, who asked you whether you heard some gun shots, who is this person who woke you up?
I don't know what his surname is.
Did you personally hear those gun shots during that night?
Yes, I did hear the gun shots.
Thank you Mr Chairperson, no further questions.

Ms Ndwane, did I hear you correctly saying that when you got to Bulelwa's corpse, that Buthelezi was there saying to you that he did not sleep the whole of the night and he was looking over the corpse?
And this is Thokozani Buthelezi's father?
He was guarding at the corpse the whole of the night?
That is what he said, he said they were guarding the corpse the whole night.
Did you see any of the SDU members there?
I don't remember seeing members of the SDU, I just saw members of the community because we had also gone to see the corpse as part of the community.  I did not really notice any member of the SDU.

Did I hear you further correctly when Mr Madasa led your evidence that you were saying that you were told that that meeting at Block F was called and that a new SDU was going to be formed?  Is that correct?
And then you were asked who called you and who told you and you said you don't know.  Is that correct?

I am not sure about that sir.  Are you saying that I said that I did not know who called the meeting, I said the meeting was called by the members of the Block, the one person that I noticed was Mr Buthelezi.
Yes, but you were asked - let me put the question to you again, when that meeting was called and when you were told to come to the meeting, did they tell you what the meeting was about?
No, you are not supposed to be told what the meeting is about when you are being called to a meeting, you hear when you are at the meeting.
So at that stage you had no knowledge of the new SDU to be formed?
At the time the meeting was called, I did not know that they were going to form a new SDU.
Thank you Chairperson.  Ms Ndwane, did Nomfundu tell you the name of the members who comprised their Executive Committee of the ANC Youth League?
You said when she came back from the meeting, she never carried any book whatsoever.  Do you recall saying so?
Did she describe what kind of Secretary she was in the Executive of the Youth League?
I am asking you this because in the bundle of documents we have here, there is one David Marema who says he was the Secretary General of the ANC Youth League during 1993.

I don't know that person.  She just told me that she was the Secretary of the ANC Youth League.  I am not sure whether I am referring to the ANC Youth League Block F, however she was the Secretary of the ANC Youth League.
Thank you Chairperson, I've got no further questions.
You were not a member of the SDU, were you?
No, I was not a member.
You did not patrol together with the SDU, did you?
How did you know that the SDU patrolled all the Blocks?
As a member of the community, I knew that the SDU patrolled all the Blocks, but I was not patrolling with them.
You were not aware of any complaints against the SDU?
Were there no complaints against the SDU from Block F?
Do you - and I take it that the SDU also patrolled Block F?
The SDU according to you, also patrolled Block F?
Did you see the members of the SDU patrolling Block F?
We would sleep at night, certain that they are patrolling the area.  I never made certain that they actually do patrol the area.
Do you know of any reason why some people in Block F would want to form a new SDU?

I think I already said that the reason I heard about was that they were forming a new SDU because they were saying that their parents were being attacked, I am not certain who exactly was attacking their parents.
Parents to the children who wanted to form a new SDU.
The meeting that you attended, was it attended by the Youth at which the decision to form a new SDU was being discussed?
I am not sure if the Youth was there, because when you talk about the ANC Youth League, it is not somebody - it is not, I cannot put a face to the ANC Youth League, I don't know the people.
Are you aware of any reason why the residents, the parents of Block F would want to form a new SDU?
I have no such knowledge because I was not a part of those parents.
No questions, thank you Mr Chairman.

Thank you Ms Ndwane.
WITNESS EXCUSED
Mr Chairman, may I call Matthews Mohlakwane?
Mr Mohlakwane, what language are you going to speak?
Thank you Mr Chair.  Mr Mohlakwane, in 1993, where did you live?
Do you know the ANC Youth League, do you know of such an organisation which existed in 1993?
I would only count two of those members of the ANC Youth League.
Sorry Mr Chairman, I didn't get that.  Did he say there were certain members he knew?  Did you say you knew some members of the ANC Youth League?
At that time, I only knew two of the members of the ANC Youth League.
It is Ndlamini and it is Lucky.
Did you belong to any organisation?
Were you part of any structure in the community?  Did you belong to any structure in the community, street committee, something like that?
Did the ANC Youth League have a problem with you?
Okay, before we come to the assault, I mean did they have a problem with you as a person?
Listen, don't rush.  Were there any allegations against you emanating from the ANC Youth League members?
Did you understand my previous questions?
I did not understand you well sir.
From where did you not understand, because you have been giving answers to a number of questions?
The last question sir ... (tape ends) ... you mean myself sir?  I did not ...
Did the ANC Youth League have a problem against you?
My brother-in-law arrived.  He was having boxes, there were shoes inside.  He said I should put those shoes in my house.
I said to him I have no space to keep those shoes in my house.
I accompanied him to Mr Zulu to ask for Mr Zulu to keep those shoes for him.
Zulu agreed that he would keep those shoes.
On that day it was Saturday afternoon.
The following day, that is on Sunday, whilst I was still at my house, Ndlamini together with a few boys arrived at my place, with those boxes.
When they arrived, I did not ask them anything.  I left.  I went to Mr Radebe's place.  Mr wife left to Kumalo.  Whilst I was still relaxing at Rabede's place, my wife arrived with a taxi.
There was a big truck.  When she alighted from the taxi, a group of boys came from that truck and attacked my wife.
That is members of the ANC Youth League.
Did you see them when they attacked your wife?
I was looking, yes, I did.
Yes, it was during the day.

Whilst they were attacking Radebe said to me, that people are attacking your wife.  Then I went there to intervene and say it is better for me to die.  When they saw me, they left my wife and came to me.
With a short gun and a rifle.
It was a group, I was not able to count them.
With what?  With what did they assault your wife?
They assaulted my wife with stones, with all those things and they were kicking her.
From Radebe's place, the three of us we were taken the three of us, we were taken to a veld.  They were saying they were going to kill us.
Who was taken to the veld, were you together with your wife?
They left my wife when I appeared, they took myself together with the other two whom I was relaxing with.
It was you and Radebe, who was the other person?
Radebe was the owner of the house, the other one was his brother-in-law, then the other one was his neighbour.  So they left Radebe and they took us, the three of us.
What did they do to you when they reached the veld?
We were taken next to the river bank where Ndlamini tied my hands at the back.  When they completed, they set fire and they sent boys to go and buy petrol.
Yes, I was tied.  Then the community came, members of the community came.  They helped us because they called these boys aside, then those men accompanied me home.
Do you know the reason for the attack, do you know why you were attacked?
Whilst I was walking, whilst I was being beaten, saying that I am informer Mowenpe.
You were accused of being an informer?
People who are called Mowenpe were Inkatha members.
Were you accused of being an informer, therefore an Inkatha member?  Were you accused of being a Mowenpe and therefore an Inkatha member?
Did anything further happen to you, after you were saved by the community?
Is there any other incident that the ANC Youth League caused which you witnessed?
Did you hear of Majosi's death?
Did you witness that?  Did you see what happened to him?
Do you know who killed them?
I learnt that it was members of the Youth.
Is there any other incident that you know of besides Majosi and yourself?

You said you learnt that the attackers of Mr Majosi were members of the Youth, were they referred to by the person who informed you as members of the ANC Youth League necessarily, or the youth of the community?
He said it was the Youth.
Thank you sir, no further questions.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Why was your wife attacked?
I do not know the reason for my wife's attack, I really do not know the reason.
Thank you, no further questions Mr Chairman.
I've got no questions, Mr Chairman.
Thank you.  Thank you Mr Mohlakwane.  You may stand down.

Mr Chairman, that is the applicant's case.
APPLICANT'S CASE
Mr Mapoma, do you intend leading evidence?
Yes, Chairperson, I intend leading evidence from the side of the victims.

Very well, we will listen to that evidence at two o'clock.  We will now take the lunch adjournment.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION
Would you perhaps outline to us, is the basis or what is the basis of the opposition?

Chairperson, the families oppose the amnesty because they say that the truth has not come out, in fact they contest most of the allegations which have been set out from the applicants' case.
	They want in a way to give their perspective of the actual events they say took place, and now in that regard, Chairperson, there are some witnesses who are members of the ANC Youth League.  One of those witnesses whom I am going to call now, Chairperson, is Tusaneng Lekabe, who has been referred to by the applicants on a number of occasions as to what happened on that day, and so he will show what actually happened and where the differences are between the versions of the applicants and the versions of the victims.
	Then we have those who were captured, but released.  Some of them feel that the way they were captured, has not been set out the way it actually happened and the injuries they suffered and the treatment they were subjected to, has not been given here.  The family members in particular the mothers, of the deceased, want to show what happened on that day and their role before their children happened to be killed, and they want to show that, in fact they say that they are particularly concerned that an impression is given that they did not respond when there children were caught, whereas they did respond, but they were chased away by the applicants.  It is along those lines, Chairperson, that this evidence is going to go.
Is it on the issue from the victims point of view, one of lack of full disclosure?

Yes Chairperson, it is lack of full disclosure, but some of the witnesses from the side of the ANC Youth League, claim that what has been done, was not politically motivated.  They have got a feeling that it was a pure criminal act.
Is the basis of the opposition therefore that one, there hasn't been a full disclosure, and secondly there was no political motive behind the killing?
Yes, very well, would you call the first witness.
How many witnesses do you propose calling Mr Mapoma?
I propose calling three witnesses Chairperson.
Are these three witnesses going to deal with the issue of full disclosure?

Yes, very well.  To the extent that it may be necessary, I think it is clear from what Mr Mapoma has said, that we will have to sit beyond today.  I would like to inform the interpreters and the recording people that we will be here on Monday and we will run from Monday until we are finished.
	Mr Lekabe, what language are you going to speak?
I am going to speak Sotho sir.
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Lekabe, during December 1993, where did you reside?
Were you a member of any local structure of the community there?

That is correct My Lord.  I was the Secretary General of our area, which is Muleleki Extension 2.  We were under the umbrella of SANCO, and I was the Secretary, Information Secretary within the Youth League.
So you were the Secretary General of the Civic Organisation?
And the Secretary of the ANC Youth League?
Did you know, do you know Bulelwa who died on the 6th of December 1993?
Yes, I know her.  She was a member of the Civic.  She was a member of the Block Committee.   Yes, I knew her.  Because she was one member of the Civic in Block F.
Now, between the ANC Youth League and SANCO was there any working relationship?
Can you describe briefly what kind of working relationship did you have?
At times we patrolled together, until there was a separation, then we were told that the SDU will be operating at night.
Sorry, I am asking the working relationship between the ANC Youth League and the Civic?
That is correct.  The Civic is a much bigger structure, taking care of all the community.  Every problem that arose, was reported to the Civic.
Were there any members of the ANC Youth League, who formed part of the Civic?
You said you were a member of the ANC Youth League, and also a member of the Civic, haven't you, you said so?
Now, can you just describe the working relationship that was there between the ANC Youth League and the Civic Organisation in Muleleki Extension?
I already said that all organisations within the township, reported to the Civic.  There was a working relationship, we did not take sides.  Everybody was accepted by the Civic.
So are you saying the ANC Youth League was also reporting to the Civic, is that what you are saying?
Now about Bulelwa in particular, was she having a working relationship with the ANC Youth League?
I would say yes because she was regarded as a leader.  She used to sit down with them and give them MRice, they liked her.
Do you recall the incident of the 6th of December 1993?

That is correct sir.  On the 6th of December 1993, round about five past, if not ten past eight at night, the deceased Buthelezi came home crying, and he was shouting, he was saying oh, please, please and I tried to calm him down.  I said Mr Buthelezi, calm down, speak so that we can understand what happened.
	He said no, comrade Bulelwa has passed away and I said how should I be of assistance.  And he said Mr Mokoena said I must come and fetch you.  There was another man, an inhabitant.
So you say that Mr Buthelezi reported that Bulelwa has been killed?  Then what did you do?

Mr Buthelezi was crying when he approached me.  He said oh, no, Bulelwa has died.  I said please calm down, you are crying, I can't hear what you are saying.
	He said Bulelwa is dead, and I am here, sent by Mr Mokoena to come and fetch you because at that time, there was another man, an ordinary inhabitant of the township.
The Mr Buthelezi that you are talking about, is that Mr Buthelezi who was killed amongst the other youth?

Okay, continue then.  Yes, I was together with another man who came to tell me something privately, and Mr Buthelezi said Mr Mokoena want me, and I wanted to go but that man who was a citizen of the township, said stop.  You know very well, you are not in very good terms with these SDU men, now it will be easy for them to catch up with you and kill you.
Were you not in good terms with the SDU's?
That is correct, we were not in good terms.
What problems did you have with the SDU's?

My Lord, I can mention many problems.  Even the community can support me on that.
	The first problem is related to when the community was saying we have an SDU, it is patrolling, but people keep on dying.  At night when we come from work, we are harassed and assaulted.
	When I was asked, they said where are you from.

No, before then.   Let's go to this SDU, don't be fast please so as to allow the interpreters.
	Now, when was the SDU formed in Muleleki?
According to my knowledge the SDU in Muleleki was formed in May if not June.
When it was formed, was the community involved?
May or June of which year?
Can you describe briefly how was it formed?

At the time Muleleki was still under construction.  They were still busy with the building of toilets, and people gradually occupied their sites.  If I remember well, people who resided in Block E and D were the first to form the SDU.
Was the community involved in the formation of the SDU's?
No, My Lord.  The community did not have an opportunity in taking part.
Now, what problems were there with the SDU's?

I said there were many problems, because as the leaders of the community, all structures were supposed to report to us as the leaders of the community, but now they did not want to subscribe to us.  They said we must subscribe under them.
When you say us, what do you mean?  As a Civic or as the ANC Youth League?
Now, as the Civic, did you call a community meeting to address the problems that you had with them?
Yes, a meeting was called to discuss this issue.
Are there any other problems which were highlighted in that meeting about the activities of the SDU's?

Yes, sir.  We explained to the community that the members of the SDU are giving us problems, the way the operate.  When we called them to come and appear before you, they don't want to, now we don't know what steps to follow.
The way they operate, what do you mean, what way did they operate?

I told you already that there were many problems, for instance when they patrolled at night, when they pass in the street and they see that your lights are still on, they get into your house, assault you, ask you why don't you go to bed.
	Some of the women were being raped, people were killed.  When they patrolled sir, when they found you outside, they would assault you.  When they pass by the road, because that place did not have street lights as yet, now when there was light in your house, they would get into your house, and ask you why don't you go to bed.
Now, let's come to this SDU.  Have you seen all the applicants?
Were the applicants part of the SDU you are talking about?
Now, when these problems were highlighted in a meeting, was the SDU present in that meeting?
They were present My Lord, because the person who was always there is Tsepo and Nxeba.
When these accusations were given against them, what was their response?
When these accusations were taken out, they were not happy at all.  They then said SANCO wants to rule them and yet, they were independent.
Is SANCO and Civic one and the same thing?
Now was ANC Youth League part of the meeting?
Yes, every organisation reported to the Civic.  They were members of the township, so they were present.
Now when these problems were highlighted, are there any members of the ANC Youth League who were saying something also about the SDU's?
Every member of the community has the right to speak at the meeting, called by the Civic.
Did members of the ANC Youth League speak at this meeting and say anything about the SDU's?
They spoke but they did not say anything bad.
Thank you Chairperson.  Now was there a specific response from the SDU to the ANC Youth League?
Yes, there is something that the SDU said.

Chairperson, I have already told you that we had problems.  They said it was better as members of the committee, Sectional Committee, shouldn't we fight with you because you don't want to understand.
	They wanted to go straight to the community, they were supposed to come to the Civic to report because everybody had to start first at the Civics.
My question is, is there anything that the SDU members said about the ANC Youth League or is there any specific response that was directed to the ANC Youth League from the SDU in that meeting?
Yes, sir there is something they said.
They said you members of the ANC Youth League, you must better keep quiet.

Okay.  Now, let's come back to the incident of the killing of Bulelwa.
	You were saying Mr Buthelezi told you that Bulelwa has been killed, and was crying and he called you.  What did you do thereafter?

I did not go, but at that time because the community heard Mr Buthelezi's cry, they came together and they said, guys you are aware that the SDU is now attacking and our leaders are now dying.
